items.text: I can easily visualize how a flat pattern would look when folded into a three-dimensional shape.
items.rationale: Mental rotation and spatial visualization are core components of perceptual reasoning.

items.text: When I look at a complex design, I can quickly identify the underlying pattern or structure.
items.rationale: Pattern recognition in visual stimuli directly taps perceptual reasoning abilities.

items.text: I'm good at figuring out how puzzle pieces fit together without needing to physically try each one.
items.rationale: Mental manipulation of spatial relationships is a hallmark of PRI tasks like Block Design.

items.text: If you show me a series of shapes with one missing, I can usually figure out which shape completes the sequence.
items.rationale: Matrix reasoning—identifying rules governing visual sequences—is a core PRI subtest.

items.text: I can look at a set of objects and quickly determine which one doesn't belong based on visual properties.
items.rationale: Visual categorization and identifying the odd-one-out maps to Picture Concepts and visual abstraction.

items.text: People say I have a natural talent for reading maps and understanding spatial layouts.
items.rationale: Spatial orientation and navigation rely on visuospatial reasoning central to PRI.

items.text: I find it easy to mentally rotate objects and imagine them from different angles.
items.rationale: Mental rotation is one of the most well-established measures of perceptual reasoning.

items.text: When assembling furniture from a diagram, I can easily translate the 2D instructions into the 3D construction.
items.rationale: Translating between 2D representations and 3D constructions requires strong visuospatial reasoning.

items.text: I can look at an abstract figure and identify the logical rule that governs its design.
items.rationale: Extracting logical rules from nonverbal visual stimuli is the essence of matrix reasoning tasks.

items.text: I notice visual details in pictures that other people tend to miss.
items.rationale: Visual detail discrimination maps to perceptual analysis tasks within PRI.

items.text: When given a set of colored blocks, I can quickly reproduce a complex geometric pattern.
items.rationale: Directly mirrors the Block Design subtest, a core PRI measure.

items.text: I'm skilled at estimating proportions and spatial relationships just by looking at things.
items.rationale: Spatial estimation and proportional reasoning are key visuospatial abilities within PRI.

items.text: I can usually figure out how mechanical devices work by examining their parts visually.
items.rationale: Mechanical reasoning involves visuospatial analysis but may also draw on acquired knowledge (VCI).

items.text: I enjoy solving visual brain teasers and find them easier than word-based puzzles.
items.rationale: Preference for visual over verbal puzzles suggests PRI strength, though enjoyment is not ability.

items.text: I can quickly spot what's missing or wrong in a picture of an everyday scene.
items.rationale: Picture Completion taps perceptual reasoning but the speed component could also reflect PSI.

items.text: I can scan a page of symbols and quickly mark the ones that match a target symbol.
items.rationale: Directly mirrors the Symbol Search subtest, a core PSI measure of rapid visual scanning.

items.text: When doing repetitive clerical tasks, I work much faster than most people while maintaining accuracy.
items.rationale: Speed and accuracy on routine clerical tasks is the operational definition of processing speed.

items.text: I can quickly copy symbols or codes from a key without needing to keep looking back at it.
items.rationale: Directly maps to the Coding subtest, requiring rapid transcription of symbol-digit pairs.

items.text: People often comment on how quickly I can process simple visual information.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of rapid visual information processing is a behavioral marker of PSI.

items.text: I can sort a large stack of papers into categories much faster than my coworkers.
items.rationale: Rapid sorting of visual stimuli into categories reflects processing speed efficiency.

items.text: When I take timed tests, the speed component rarely holds me back—I finish well before time is up.
items.rationale: Consistent ability to complete timed tasks quickly is a direct behavioral indicator of PSI.

items.text: I find it easy to quickly compare two strings of numbers or letters and spot the differences.
items.rationale: Rapid comparison and discrimination of visual stimuli is central to processing speed tasks.

items.text: My handwriting speed is notably fast when I need to copy text or symbols.
items.rationale: Graphomotor speed during copying tasks is a component measured by PSI subtests like Coding.

items.text: I can learn a new simple coding system—like matching symbols to numbers—very rapidly.
items.rationale: Rapid acquisition and execution of simple coding rules directly reflects Coding subtest performance.

items.text: In data entry tasks, I maintain a high rate of speed with very few errors.
items.rationale: Speed-accuracy tradeoff performance on routine data tasks is a real-world analog of PSI.

items.text: I can quickly scan a crowded visual display and locate a specific target item.
items.rationale: Visual search speed is a fundamental component of the Symbol Search subtest.

items.text: When proofreading, I catch typographical errors very quickly because I process text at a fast rate.
items.rationale: Rapid detection of visual discrepancies in text reflects processing speed efficiency.

items.text: I tend to react quickly in situations that require a fast but simple decision.
items.rationale: Simple reaction time relates to processing speed but also involves motor and attentional components.

items.text: I can quickly memorize a set of symbol-number pairings and reproduce them from memory.
items.rationale: Incidental learning of symbol-number pairs occurs in Coding but also involves working memory encoding.

items.text: I can rapidly switch between two simple tasks without much slowdown in my performance.
items.rationale: Task switching speed involves processing speed but also executive control aspects related to WMI.

items.text: I have an extensive vocabulary and can usually find the precise word to express what I mean.
items.rationale: Vocabulary breadth and precision directly maps to the Vocabulary subtest, a core VCI measure.

items.text: I can clearly explain how two seemingly different concepts are actually related.
items.rationale: Identifying abstract relationships between concepts mirrors the Similarities subtest of VCI.

items.text: When someone asks me to define a word, I can provide a thorough and nuanced explanation.
items.rationale: Providing detailed word definitions is the direct task of the Vocabulary subtest.

items.text: I have a strong grasp of general knowledge about history, science, and current events.
items.rationale: Breadth of general knowledge maps to the Information subtest, a supplemental VCI measure.

items.text: I can easily identify the abstract category that links two different words or ideas together.
items.rationale: Verbal abstract categorization is the core skill measured by the Similarities subtest.

items.text: I understand and can explain common proverbs and their deeper meanings.
items.rationale: Proverb interpretation requires verbal abstraction and crystallized verbal knowledge central to VCI.

items.text: People often come to me when they need something explained in clear, articulate language.
items.rationale: Being sought out for verbal explanations reflects strong verbal comprehension and expression.

items.text: I can readily explain why certain social rules and conventions exist in society.
items.rationale: Understanding social conventions and their rationale maps to the Comprehension subtest of VCI.

items.text: I enjoy reading challenging texts and rarely need to look up unfamiliar words.
items.rationale: Comfort with advanced vocabulary in context reflects strong crystallized verbal ability.

items.text: When asked what to do in a hypothetical social dilemma, I can articulate a well-reasoned response.
items.rationale: Verbal reasoning about social situations maps to the Comprehension subtest.

items.text: I can explain the difference between two closely related concepts with precision and clarity.
items.rationale: Fine-grained verbal discrimination between related concepts reflects advanced verbal comprehension.

items.text: I tend to pick up new languages or technical terminology faster than most people.
items.rationale: Rapid acquisition of verbal-linguistic material reflects strong crystallized verbal ability.

items.text: I can draw meaningful analogies between concepts from very different domains of knowledge.
items.rationale: Cross-domain analogical reasoning is primarily verbal but also involves fluid reasoning aspects of PRI.

items.text: I retain factual information from books and lectures much better than most people I know.
items.rationale: Long-term retention of verbal information reflects crystallized intelligence but also involves memory processes.

items.text: I can quickly come up with multiple synonyms for a given word and explain their subtle differences.
items.rationale: Rapid word retrieval involves vocabulary knowledge (VCI) but the speed component may also tap PSI or WMI retrieval fluency.

items.text: I can hold a long sequence of numbers in my head and repeat them back accurately.
items.rationale: Digit span forward is a core subtest of WMI measuring basic auditory short-term memory capacity.

items.text: If someone reads me a list of numbers, I can easily repeat them back in reverse order.
items.rationale: Digit span backward directly measures working memory manipulation, a core WMI task.

items.text: I can do mental arithmetic—like adding several numbers in my head—without writing anything down.
items.rationale: Mental arithmetic requires holding and manipulating numerical information, directly mapping to the Arithmetic subtest.

items.text: When someone gives me a phone number verbally, I can remember it long enough to dial it without writing it down.
items.rationale: Retaining a digit string in auditory short-term memory is a real-world analog of Digit Span.

items.text: I can listen to a series of letters and numbers mixed together and then sort them into the correct order in my head.
items.rationale: Directly mirrors the Letter-Number Sequencing subtest, requiring simultaneous storage and reordering.

items.text: I find it easy to keep track of multiple pieces of information simultaneously while solving a problem.
items.rationale: Simultaneous maintenance and processing of multiple information elements is the definition of working memory.

items.text: When following multi-step verbal instructions, I rarely need to ask for them to be repeated.
items.rationale: Retaining and executing multi-step verbal instructions requires robust auditory working memory.

items.text: I can solve word problems in my head by holding all the relevant numbers and operations in memory at once.
items.rationale: Mental word problem solving requires maintaining verbal information while performing calculations, mapping to Arithmetic.

items.text: During conversations, I can easily keep track of several different points being discussed and return to each one.
items.rationale: Tracking multiple conversational threads requires active maintenance and updating of information in working memory.

items.text: I can mentally rearrange a scrambled sequence of items into alphabetical or numerical order without writing them down.
items.rationale: Mental resequencing of items is the core operation in Letter-Number Sequencing.

items.text: When calculating a tip at a restaurant, I can easily do the math in my head even with a large group.
items.rationale: Real-world mental arithmetic with multiple values maps directly to the Arithmetic subtest of WMI.

items.text: I rarely lose my place when performing a complex mental calculation with several intermediate steps.
items.rationale: Maintaining intermediate results during multi-step mental computation is a hallmark of strong working memory.

items.text: I can listen to a news report and accurately recall the key facts and figures mentioned afterward.
items.rationale: Auditory retention of factual content involves working memory but also overlaps with crystallized knowledge encoding (VCI).

items.text: I find it easy to follow along with complex arguments that involve holding several premises in mind at once.
items.rationale: Tracking logical premises requires working memory but also verbal reasoning abilities associated with VCI.

items.text: I can quickly calculate percentages and proportions in my head when comparing prices while shopping.
items.rationale: Mental calculation involves working memory, but the emphasis on speed could also reflect processing speed (PSI).
